[Association football](/wiki/Association_football "Association football") is
the most popular [sport in Spain](/wiki/Sport_in_Spain "Sport in Spain"),
followed by basketball and bullfighting. Football is a widespread passion
among the people of [Spain](/wiki/Spain "Spain").[1] Football is the sport
with the most registered players (a total of 942,674 of which 898,551 are men
and 44,123 women), and most registered clubs (a total of 20,588) among all
Spanish sport federations according to data issued by the sports
administration of Spain’s government in 2016.[2]

In a survey of sports habits of the Spanish population made in 2010, football
was the second most popular recreational sport practised by the population
(17.9%). A total of 75.9% of people said they had ever bought tickets to
attend a football match. In addition, a total of 67.3% of the people said that
they saw all, almost all, many, or some of the football matches broadcast on
television.[3] In another survey made in 2014, the practice of football
decreased to 14% of the population, being overtaken by other sports, such as
running, cycling and swimming for recreation. However, in this survey football
was still the sport that interests the majority of Spain’s people (48%). A
total of 67% of the population said they were fans or had sympathy for a
particular club. In addition, 74.9% said they watched, whenever possible, the
matches broadcast on television regarding their favorite teams; and 42.4% had,
flags, badges or objects of their favorite teams.[4] Data of this survey
confirmed the widespread impression that most of Spain’s people are supporters
of [Real Madrid](/wiki/Real_Madrid "Real Madrid") (37.9%) or [FC
Barcelona](/wiki/FC_Barcelona "FC Barcelona") (25.4%), and the other teams
have fewer supporters nationwide, as [Atlético de
Madrid](/wiki/Atl%C3%A9tico_de_Madrid "Atlético de Madrid") (16.1%), [Valencia
CF](/wiki/Valencia_CF "Valencia CF") (3.5%), [Athletic
Bilbao](/wiki/Athletic_Bilbao "Athletic Bilbao") (3.3.) or [Sevilla
FC](/wiki/Sevilla_FC "Sevilla FC") (3.2%).[4]

A relationship between football, politics, identity and attitudes towards
regionalism in Spain has also been reported.[1][5][6][7][8]

The [Royal Spanish Football
Federation](/wiki/Royal_Spanish_Football_Federation "Royal Spanish Football
Federation") (Spanish: Real Federación Española de Fútbol) is the national
governing body, and it organises two Cup competitions (the [Copa del
Rey](/wiki/Copa_del_Rey "Copa del Rey"), and the [Supercopa de
España](/wiki/Supercopa_de_Espa%C3%B1a "Supercopa de España")), and the [Spain
national football team](/wiki/Spain_national_football_team "Spain national
football team"). The _[Liga de Fútbol
Profesional](/wiki/Liga_de_F%C3%BAtbol_Profesional "Liga de Fútbol
Profesional")_ (LFP) (English: Professional Football League), integrated by a
total of 42 football clubs, forms part of the Royal Spanish Football
Federation (RFEF) but has autonomy in its organisation and functioning. It is
responsible for the organisation of state football leagues, in coordination
with RFEF.[9]

The [Spanish national football team](/wiki/Spain_national_football_team "Spain
national football team") have won the [FIFA World Cup](/wiki/FIFA_World_Cup
"FIFA World Cup") once, and has also been successful in the [UEFA European
Championship](/wiki/UEFA_European_Championship "UEFA European Championship")
and the [Olympic tournament](/wiki/Football_at_the_Summer_Olympics "Football
at the Summer Olympics"). The biggest success achieved by the [Spain national
football team](/wiki/Spain_national_football_team "Spain national football
team") was the historic treble winning three tournaments in a row: [UEFA
European Championship](/wiki/UEFA_European_Championship "UEFA European
Championship") in 2008, [FIFA World Cup](/wiki/FIFA_World_Cup "FIFA World
Cup") in 2010, and [UEFA European
Championship](/wiki/UEFA_European_Championship "UEFA European Championship")
in 2012.[10][11][12][13] The men's national teams of Spain, in all categories,
have won a total of 26 titles in [FIFA](/wiki/FIFA "FIFA"), [UEFA](/wiki/UEFA
"UEFA"), and [Olympic](/wiki/Football_at_the_Summer_Olympics "Football at the
Summer Olympics") tournaments.[14][15]

The First Division of the [Liga de Fútbol
Profesional](/wiki/Liga_de_F%C3%BAtbol_Profesional "Liga de Fútbol
Profesional"), commonly known in the English-speaking world as [La
Liga](/wiki/La_Liga "La Liga"), is one of the strongest football leagues in
both Europe and the world.[16][17][18] At club level, the Spanish football
clubs have won a total of 66 international tournaments. [19][20][21][22] They
are the most successful in different current European competitions, such as
[UEFA Champions League](/wiki/UEFA_Champions_League "UEFA Champions
League"),[23] [UEFA Super Cup](/wiki/UEFA_Super_Cup "UEFA Super Cup")
(shared),[24] and [UEFA Europa League](/wiki/UEFA_Europa_League "UEFA Europa
League");[25] and they also were the most successful in the extinct [Inter-
Cities Fairs Cup](/wiki/Inter-Cities_Fairs_Cup "Inter-Cities Fairs Cup").[22]

The characteristic football style of play developed by [FC
Barcelona](/wiki/FC_Barcelona "FC Barcelona"), and later by the [Spanish
national football team](/wiki/Spain_national_football_team "Spain national
football team") is [Tiki-taka](/wiki/Tiki-taka "Tiki-taka"). This football
style is characterised by possessing the ball for large portions of the game,
moving the ball quickly from one player to the next, with short and quick
passes, keeping the ball away from your opponent, and then to deliver that
killer pass to score goal.[26][27]

Professional football in Spain is a sociocultural event that make a
significant contribution to the Spanish economy in terms of both demand and
supply. In economic terms, during 2013 professional football generated more
than €7.6 billion including direct, indirect and induced effects, representing
0.75% of Spanish GPD.[28] Moreover, as a result of financial crisis in the
last years, many Spanish football clubs in the top two divisions have been
facing serious economic troubles due to pay the bank debts. In addition, the
European Union authorities have warned to Spanish authorities in order to halt
public funding of debt-ridden clubs.[29]

[Spain national futsal team](/wiki/Spain_national_futsal_team "Spain national
futsal team") is one of the strongest teams in the world, being six times
champion in the [UEFA Futsal Championship](/wiki/UEFA_Futsal_Championship
"UEFA Futsal Championship"), and two times champion in the [FIFA Futsal World
Championship](/wiki/FIFA_Futsal_World_Championship "FIFA Futsal World
Championship").[15]

## History[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Football_in_Spain&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: History")]

Modern football was introduced to Spain in the late 19th century by a
combination of mostly British immigrant workers, visiting sailors and Spanish
students coming from Britain.[30][31][32]

The oldest football clubs in Spain are [Recreativo de
Huelva](/wiki/Recreativo_de_Huelva "Recreativo de Huelva") and [Sevilla
FC](/wiki/Sevilla_FC "Sevilla FC").[33][34][35][36] Although [Gimnàstic de
Tarragona](/wiki/Gimn%C3%A0stic_de_Tarragona "Gimnàstic de Tarragona") was
formed in 1886, the club did not form an actual football team until 1914. The
first official football game played in Spain took place in
[Seville](/wiki/Seville "Seville") on 8 March 1890 at the Tablada Hippodrome.
Sevilla FC played against Recreativo de Huelva. With the exception of two
Spanish players on the [Huelva](/wiki/Huelva "Huelva") team and another two
players on the [Seville](/wiki/Seville "Seville") team, all the players on
both sides were British. Sevilla FC won 2–0.[31]

In the [Basque Country](/wiki/Basque_Country_\(autonomous_community\) "Basque
Country \(autonomous community\)") during the early 1890s, British shipyard
workers and miners formed the [Bilbao Football Club](/wiki/Athletic_Bilbao
"Athletic Bilbao") and [Basque](/wiki/Basque_people "Basque people") students
returning from Britain founded the [Athletic Club](/wiki/Athletic_Bilbao
"Athletic Bilbao") in 1898.[31][32] This early British influence was reflected
in the use of English names such as _Recreation Club_ , _Athletic Club_ and
_Football Club_.[32]

In Catalonia, which had the most developed industry in Spain, there was an
important British colony. The first games played by Britishmen and Catalan
people who had studied in the United Kingdom were documented in 1882 in
[Barcelona](/wiki/Barcelona "Barcelona").[31] However, the first official and
registered football club was Palamós FC (Costa Brava, North of Catalonia) in
1898.[31] The Swiss [Hans Gamper](/wiki/Joan_Gamper "Joan Gamper") founded [FC
Barcelona](/wiki/FC_Barcelona "FC Barcelona") on 29 November 1899.[31] Other
clubs were founded in 1900, such as Sant Andreu, Hispania FC and the Sociedad
Española de Football (one year later the founders changed the name to [Real
Club Deportivo Español](/wiki/RCD_Espanyol "RCD Espanyol")).[31] The [Catalan
Football Federation](/wiki/Catalan_Football_Federation "Catalan Football
Federation") (Catalan: _Federació Catalana de Futbol_), responsible for
administering football in Catalonia, was the first football association
founded in Spain. It was formed on 11 November 1900 as the Football
Association of Catalonia (Catalan: _Football Associació de Catalunya_).[31]
The Catalan Football Federation organised the [Catalan football
championship](/wiki/Catalan_football_championship "Catalan football
championship") (Catalan: _Campionat de Catalunya_) that was the first football
competition in Spain.[31]

In [Madrid](/wiki/Madrid "Madrid"), the first games were promoted by
[Institución Libre de
Enseñanza](/wiki/Instituci%C3%B3n_Libre_de_Ense%C3%B1anza "Institución Libre
de Enseñanza") (ILE) (English: Free Educational Institution), an educational
and cultural centre. The first club of Madrid was Football Club Sky, founded
in 1897, but the club separated into two new clubs in 1890. Then, several
clubs also emerged in Madrid, most notably [_Madrid Football
Club_](/wiki/Real_Madrid_C.F. "Real Madrid C.F."), founded in 1902 by Catalan
brothers Juan and Carlos Padrós.[31]

The [Copa del Rey](/wiki/Copa_del_Rey "Copa del Rey") (English: King's Cup)
competition was founded in 1903, one year after a previous football tournament
named Coronation Cup. It was Spain's football national Championship from 1903
until the establishment of the League Championship in 1928.[37]

The Spanish Federation of Football Clubs was formed in 1909, but there were
discrepancies between the member clubs years later, and some of the clubs
formed other association called Royal Spanish Union of Clubs of Football.[38]
Finally, the two associations reached an agreement and the [Royal Spanish
Football Federation](/wiki/Royal_Spanish_Football_Federation "Royal Spanish
Football Federation") was founded in 1913, which allowed the Spanish football
to enter in [FIFA](/wiki/FIFA "FIFA").[39] In these years,
[Athletic](/wiki/Athletic_Bilbao "Athletic Bilbao") was the most dominant club
in the country, and the first idols in Spain began to appear, like
[Pichichi](/wiki/Rafael_Moreno_Aranzadi "Rafael Moreno Aranzadi") and [Paulino
Alcántara](/wiki/Paulino_Alc%C3%A1ntara "Paulino Alcántara").[39][40][41]

The [Spain national team](/wiki/Spain_national_football_team "Spain national
football team") was created in 1920 on the occasion of the dispute of the
Olympic Games in [Antwerp](/wiki/Antwerp "Antwerp").[32][41] The importance of
the success of the Spain national team in the Olympic games, which won the
silver medal, was huge in the development of football as mass social event in
Spain.[41] The interest on football grew, more people attended to the
stadiums, more informations about football appeared in the newspapers, and
football was used as element of national prestige and political
propaganda.[42]

After the Olympic triumph, football was more popular among Spanish fans, the
attendances to the stadiums increased, and the pressure of professionalism
grew.[43] Spanish football turned professional in 1925.[44] An agreement
between several clubs was made on 23 November 1928 which officially
established Spain's national football division, and the birth of the [Spanish
League](/wiki/La_Liga "La Liga"). The first league championship began in
1929.[32][45]

The [Spanish Civil War](/wiki/Spanish_Civil_War "Spanish Civil War")
(1936–1939) brought disruption to the national competitions. Although the
Spanish League was suspended, the Catalan and Valencian clubs continued
contesting in the Mediterranean League in early 1937. Barcelona later toured
Mexico and the United States, raising support for the Spanish Republic.[32]

The Spanish League and the Cup were restored in the 1939–40 season after Civil
War had ended. [Francisco Franco’s regime](/wiki/Francoist_Spain "Francoist
Spain"), a fascist political system, began to use football as a propaganda
tool for the new regime.[46] In 1941, as part of his policy of eradicating
regional identities, the Franco's regime banned the use of non-Castilian
names. As a result, many clubs that had chosen English prefixes previously,
such as Athletic or Football club, had to amend their initial names, for other
Castilian (as Atlético, or Club de Fútbol). The [Catalan
Championship](/wiki/Catalan_football_championship "Catalan football
championship") was banned and the Catalan shield taken from FC Barcelona's
badge. Spanish football began to rebuild slowly after the War, but Spain's
isolated international position meant they did not properly re-enter
International football until 1950.[32] Later, Franco's regime was able to use
the football, based on the European triumphs of Real Madrid in the 1950s for
political purposes. In this manner, Real Madrid was used as a Spanish brand of
success to promote Spain’s image abroad, as well as the pride of being Spanish
in the country itself.[7][47]

Spain was selected as host of the [1982 FIFA World
Cup](/wiki/1982_FIFA_World_Cup "1982 FIFA World Cup").

Until the 1984–85 season, the Royal Spanish Football Federation (RFEF) was
responsible for organizing the league tournament. Since then, the competition
was organized by the [Liga de Fútbol
Profesional](/wiki/Liga_de_F%C3%BAtbol_Profesional "Liga de Fútbol
Profesional") (LFP)(English: Professional Football League), an independent
body which was formed at the initiative of the clubs themselves after
disagreements with the RFEF regarding the management professionalization and
economic division of the League benefits.

Since the entry into force of Spanish Law 10/1990, almost all of the clubs
competing professionally in Spain are actually companies under the legal
status of sports companies, whose ownership is in the hands of its
shareholders. Only three professional clubs ([Athletic
Club](/wiki/Atl%C3%A9tico_Madrid "Atlético Madrid"), Barcelona and Real
Madrid) kept its original structure, such as sports clubs directly controlled
by their members.

After the appearance of private television in Spain, football clubs hugely
increased its income thanks to the lucrative contracts to broadcast matches on
television. This allowed them to hire many of the best players in the world,
but most of the clubs also increased vastly their spending. In the last years
[La Liga](/wiki/La_Liga "La Liga") is living in a big financial turmoil.
Although the two big powerful clubs, Real Madrid and Barcelona, are at the top
in _[Forbes](/wiki/Forbes "Forbes")'_ football rich list, the rest of Spanish
clubs are weighed down by a colossal debt around €4.1 billion. For this
reason, most of the clubs had to cut their budgets drastically.[48]

## Spanish national football team (_La
Roja_)[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Football_in_Spain&action=edit&section=2 "Edit
section: Spanish national football team \(La Roja\)")]

Main article: [Spain national football
team](/wiki/Spain_national_football_team "Spain national football team")

Main article: [List of Spain international
footballers](/wiki/List_of_Spain_international_footballers "List of Spain
international footballers")

Within Spain, regional teams, most notably the [football team of
Catalonia](/wiki/Catalonia_national_football_team "Catalonia national football
team"), the [football team of Basque
Country](/wiki/Basque_Country_national_football_team "Basque Country national
football team"), and even the [football team of
Galicia](/wiki/Galicia_national_football_team "Galicia national football
team"), began to compete against each other from 1915 onwards. Despite not
being officially recognised by [FIFA](/wiki/FIFA "FIFA"), these regional teams
still occasionally play friendly games with some national team players playing
for both teams. Some autonomous governments and social sectors in the
historical communities (especially in [Catalonia](/wiki/Catalonia "Catalonia")
and [Basque Country](/wiki/Basque_Country_\(autonomous_community\) "Basque
Country \(autonomous community\)")) prefer to call their regional teams as
national team, while claiming to participate in international tournaments.[49]

The [Spain national team](/wiki/Spain_national_football_team "Spain national
football team"), commonly referred to as _La selección_ (English: The
selection) or _La Roja_ (English: The Red one), made their international debut
at the [1920 Olympic Games](/wiki/Football_at_the_1920_Summer_Olympics
"Football at the 1920 Summer Olympics") in Belgium and came away with the
silver medal.[32][41] Since then the Spanish national team has participated in
a total of fourteen out twenty [FIFA World Cup](/wiki/FIFA_World_Cup "FIFA
World Cup") and nine out fourteen [UEFA European
Championship](/wiki/UEFA_European_Championship "UEFA European Championship").
Historically, the Spanish national team did not achieve important results, in
terms of trophies or develop an attractive playing style. Surprisingly, this
fact contrasted with the huge success obtained by the main Spanish football
clubs at the European level. Nevertheless, the triumphs of Spanish national
team in [2008](/wiki/UEFA_Euro_2008 "UEFA Euro 2008") and [2012 European
Championship](/wiki/UEFA_Euro_2012 "UEFA Euro 2012"), and in [2010 FIFA World
Cup](/wiki/2010_FIFA_World_Cup "2010 FIFA World Cup"), with an [attractive
playing style](/wiki/Tiki-taka "Tiki-taka"), marked a point of inflection that
divided the history of Spanish national football team in two parts.

The Spanish national football team has been the winner of [FIFA Team of
Year](/wiki/FIFA_World_Ranking "FIFA World Ranking") in 2008, 2009, 2010,
2011, 2012 and 2013, as well as the winner of [Laureus World Sports Award for
Team of the Year](/wiki/Laureus_World_Sports_Award_for_Team_of_the_Year
"Laureus World Sports Award for Team of the Year") in 2011.

The Spanish national football team have won four trophies in FIFA and
[UEFA](/wiki/UEFA "UEFA") tournaments: one [FIFA World
Cup](/wiki/FIFA_World_Cup "FIFA World Cup") in 2010, and three [UEFA European
Championship](/wiki/UEFA_European_Championship "UEFA European Championship")
in 1964, 2008 and 2012. In addition, it was runner-up in the UEFA European
Championship in [1984](/wiki/UEFA_Euro_1984 "UEFA Euro 1984") and in the [FIFA
Confederations Cup](/wiki/FIFA_Confederations_Cup "FIFA Confederations Cup")
in [2013](/wiki/2013_FIFA_Confederations_Cup "2013 FIFA Confederations Cup").

The [Spain national under-23 team](/wiki/Spain_national_under-23_football_team
"Spain national under-23 football team") won the gold medal in 1992 [Olympic
tournament](/wiki/Football_at_the_Summer_Olympics "Football at the Summer
Olympics") and the silver medal in 2000.

The Spain national football team won the gold medal at [the Mediterranean
Games](/wiki/Football_at_the_Mediterranean_Games "Football at the
Mediterranean Games") in 2005 and 2007, the silver medal in 1955, and the
bronze medal in 1963 and 1967.

In addition, the honours list includes numerous titles at junior level teams:

[UEFA European Under-21
Championship](/wiki/UEFA_European_Under-21_Championship "UEFA European
Under-21 Championship") in 1986, 1998, 2011, and 2013.

[FIFA U-20 World Cup](/wiki/FIFA_U-20_World_Cup "FIFA U-20 World Cup") in
1999.

[UEFA European Under-19
Championship](/wiki/UEFA_European_Under-19_Championship "UEFA European
Under-19 Championship") (formerly Under-18) in 1995, 2002, 2004, 2006, 2007,
2011 2012 and 2015.

[UEFA European Under-17
Championship](/wiki/UEFA_European_Under-17_Championship "UEFA European
Under-17 Championship") (formerly Under-16) in 1986, 1988, 1991, 1997, 1999,
2001, 2007 and 2008.

[1999 Meridian Cup](/wiki/1999_UEFA%E2%80%93CAF_Meridian_Cup "1999 UEFA–CAF
Meridian Cup").

Spain have won the Maurice Burlaz Trophy, the prize awarded to the national
association that has achieved the best results in UEFA's men's youth
competitions (UEFA European Under-19 Championship and UEFA European Under-17
championship) over the previous two seasons, in 1994, 1996, 1998, 2002, 2004,
2006, 2007, and 2011.[50]

include:

"Andoni Zubizarreta") (1970s/1990s), [Iker Casillas](/wiki/Iker_Casillas "Iker

Midfielders: [Josep Samitier](/wiki/Josep_Samitier "Josep Samitier")
(1920s/1930s), [Martín Marculeta](/wiki/Mart%C3%ADn_Marculeta "Martín
Marculeta") (1920s/1930s), [Leonardo Cilaurren](/wiki/Leonardo_Cilaurren
"Leonardo Cilaurren") (1920s/1930s), [José Luis
Panizo](/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_Luis_Panizo "José Luis Panizo") (1940s/1950s),
[Antonio Puchades](/wiki/Antonio_Puchades "Antonio Puchades") (1940s/1950s),
[Alfredo Di Stéfano](/wiki/Alfredo_Di_St%C3%A9fano "Alfredo Di Stéfano")
(1950s/1960s), [Luis del Sol](/wiki/Luis_del_Sol "Luis del Sol")
(1960s/1970s), [Luis Suárez](/wiki/Luis_Su%C3%A1rez_\(footballer,_born_1935\)
"Luis Suárez \(footballer, born 1935\)") (1960s/1970s), [Luis

## Football club
competitions[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Football_in_Spain&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Football club competitions")]

Main article: [List of football clubs in
Spain](/wiki/List_of_football_clubs_in_Spain "List of football clubs in
Spain")

Main article: [Football records in Spain](/wiki/Football_records_in_Spain
"Football records in Spain")

Currently, the three most important competitions between clubs in Spain are La
Liga (English: League), the Copa del Rey (English: King's Cup) and the
Supercopa de España (English: Spanish Supercup). Other extinct competitions
were the [League Cup](/wiki/Copa_de_la_Liga "Copa de la Liga"), the [Eva
Duarte Cup](/wiki/Copa_Eva_Duarte "Copa Eva Duarte") and the President's Cup
of the Spanish Football Federation. Up to a total of fifteen clubs have been
winners of some of the official competitions in Spain at the highest level,
and [FC Barcelona](/wiki/FC_Barcelona "FC Barcelona") is the most awarded club
with seventy-two national titles,

The [Spanish football league system](/wiki/Spanish_football_league_system
"Spanish football league system") consists of several leagues bound together
hierarchically by promotion and relegation. In addition, [Spanish Royal
Federation Cup](/wiki/Spanish_Royal_Federation_Cup "Spanish Royal Federation
Cup") is a football competition for teams from the Segunda División B, the
Tercera División and sometimes from the Preferente Regional who have failed to
qualify or have been eliminated in the first round of the Copa del Rey.

## League (La
Liga)[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Football_in_Spain&action=edit&section=4 "Edit
section: League \(La Liga\)")]

Main article: [La Liga](/wiki/La_Liga "La Liga")

Main article: [List of Spanish football
champions](/wiki/List_of_Spanish_football_champions "List of Spanish football
champions")

Main article: [Football records in Spain](/wiki/Football_records_in_Spain
"Football records in Spain")

In April 1927, Álvaro Trejo, a director at [Arenas Club de
Getxo](/wiki/Arenas_Club_de_Getxo "Arenas Club de Getxo"), first proposed the
idea of a national league in Spain. After much debate about the size of the
league and who would take part, the
[RFEF](/wiki/Royal_Spanish_Football_Federation "Royal Spanish Football
Federation") eventually agreed on the ten teams who would form the first
_Primera División_ in 1928. [FC Barcelona](/wiki/FC_Barcelona "FC Barcelona"),
[Real Madrid](/wiki/Real_Madrid_C.F. "Real Madrid C.F."), [Athletic
Bilbao](/wiki/Athletic_Bilbao "Athletic Bilbao"), [Real
Sociedad](/wiki/Real_Sociedad "Real Sociedad"), [Arenas Club de
Getxo](/wiki/Arenas_Club_de_Getxo "Arenas Club de Getxo") and [Real
Unión](/wiki/Real_Uni%C3%B3n "Real Unión") were all selected as previous
winners of the [Copa del Rey](/wiki/Copa_del_Rey "Copa del Rey"). [Athletic
Madrid](/wiki/Atl%C3%A9tico_Madrid "Atlético Madrid"), [RCD
Español](/wiki/RCD_Espanyol "RCD Espanyol") and [CE Europa](/wiki/CE_Europa
"CE Europa") qualified as [Copa del Rey](/wiki/Copa_del_Rey "Copa del Rey")
runners-up and [Racing de Santander](/wiki/Racing_de_Santander "Racing de
Santander") qualified through a knock-out competition against [Sevilla
FC](/wiki/Sevilla_FC "Sevilla FC"). Barcelona was the first winner of the
competition. Only three of the founding clubs, Real Madrid, Barcelona and
Athletic Bilbao, have never been relegated from the _Primera Division_ ; six
other clubs have never been below the top two tiers:
[Sevilla](/wiki/Sevilla_FC "Sevilla FC"), Real Sociedad, [Sporting de
Gijón](/wiki/Sporting_de_Gij%C3%B3n "Sporting de Gijón"),
[Valencia](/wiki/Valencia_CF "Valencia CF"), Espanyol and Atlético Madrid.

Historically, some of the best football players in the world have played in
the Spanish football league, including [Ricardo Zamora](/wiki/Ricardo_Zamora
"Ricardo Zamora"), [Josep Samitier](/wiki/Josep_Samitier "Josep Samitier"),
[Alfredo Di Stéfano](/wiki/Alfredo_Di_St%C3%A9fano "Alfredo Di Stéfano"),
[Ladislav Kubala](/wiki/Ladislav_Kubala "Ladislav Kubala"), [Ferenc
Puskás](/wiki/Ferenc_Pusk%C3%A1s "Ferenc Puskás"), [Raymond
Kopa](/wiki/Raymond_Kopa "Raymond Kopa"), [Héctor Rial](/wiki/H%C3%A9ctor_Rial
"Héctor Rial"), [Telmo Zarra](/wiki/Telmo_Zarra "Telmo Zarra"), [Francisco
Gento](/wiki/Francisco_Gento "Francisco Gento"), [Luis
Suárez](/wiki/Luis_Suarez_\(footballer,_born_1935\) "Luis Suarez \(footballer,
born 1935\)"), [Johan Cruyff](/wiki/Johan_Cruyff "Johan Cruyff"), [Diego
Maradona](/wiki/Diego_Maradona "Diego Maradona"), [Bernd
Schuster](/wiki/Bernd_Schuster "Bernd Schuster"), [Andoni
Zubizarreta](/wiki/Andoni_Zubizarreta "Andoni Zubizarreta"), [Michael
Laudrup](/wiki/Michael_Laudrup "Michael Laudrup"), [Hristo
Stoichkov](/wiki/Hristo_Stoichkov "Hristo Stoichkov"),
[Romário](/wiki/Rom%C3%A1rio "Romário"), [Zinedine
Zidane](/wiki/Zinedine_Zidane "Zinedine Zidane"), [Rivaldo](/wiki/Rivaldo
"Rivaldo"), [Ronaldo](/wiki/Ronaldo_\(Brazilian_footballer\) "Ronaldo
\(Brazilian footballer\)"), [Raúl](/wiki/Ra%C3%BAl_\(footballer\) "Raúl
\(footballer\)"), [Ronaldinho](/wiki/Ronaldinho "Ronaldinho"), [Carles
Puyol](/wiki/Carles_Puyol "Carles Puyol"), [Xavi](/wiki/Xavi "Xavi"), [Andrés
Iniesta](/wiki/Andr%C3%A9s_Iniesta "Andrés Iniesta"), [Iker
Casillas](/wiki/Iker_Casillas "Iker Casillas"), [Cristiano
Ronaldo](/wiki/Cristiano_Ronaldo "Cristiano Ronaldo"), and [Lionel
Messi](/wiki/Lionel_Messi "Lionel Messi"), among others.

[La Liga de Fútbol Profesional](/wiki/La_Liga_de_F%C3%BAtbol_Profesional "La
Liga de Fútbol Profesional") (LFP) is the association responsible for
administering the two professional football leagues in Spain. Professional
Spanish football is divided into the _Primera División_ (First Division) and
_Segunda División_ (Second Division). The First Division is also known as Liga
Santander, for sponsorship reasons, while the Second Division is officially
called [Liga 1|2|3](/wiki/Segunda_Divisi%C3%B3n "Segunda División"). The First
Division consists of 20 professional teams and the Second Division has 22.
There are also lower Spanish national football divisions. Every year, the
three lowest ranked teams in the First Division pass to the Second Division
and the top three ranked teams in the Second Division pass to the First
Division.

La Liga is one of the most popular professional sports leagues in the world.
[51] The average stadium attendance was 21,000 in the 2014–15 season, with a
range of average attendance from 4,780 people in the stadium with the lowest
average attendance to 77,632 people in the stadium with highest average
attendance.[52]

In La Liga's 89-year history (with the exeception of the three seasons that
the league was suspended due to the civil war), Barcelona and Real Madrid have
won 55 titles between them. Barcelona and Real Madrid are two fierce rivals
clubs, and the matches between both two clubs are named as _[El
Clásico](/wiki/El_Cl%C3%A1sico "El Clásico")_.[8] Those football matches are
one of the most viewed sports events in the world.

Although a total of 62 teams have competed in La Liga since its inception,
only nine clubs have won the title: Real Madrid (33), Barcelona (25), Atlético
Madrid (10), Athletic Bilbao (8), Valencia (6), Real Sociedad (2), Sevilla
(1), [Deportivo de La Coruña](/wiki/Deportivo_de_La_Coru%C3%B1a "Deportivo de
La Coruña") (1), and [Real Betis](/wiki/Real_Betis "Real Betis") (1).

## King's Cup (Copa del
Rey)[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Football_in_Spain&action=edit&section=5 "Edit
section: King's Cup \(Copa del Rey\)")]

Main article: [Copa del Rey](/wiki/Copa_del_Rey "Copa del Rey")

Main article: [Football records in Spain](/wiki/Football_records_in_Spain
"Football records in Spain")

In 1902, [Carlos Padrós](/wiki/Carlos_Padr%C3%B3s "Carlos Padrós"), later
president of Madrid FC (later to be Real Madrid), suggested a football
competition to celebrate the coronation of [Alfonso XIII](/wiki/Alfonso_XIII
"Alfonso XIII"). Four other teams entered the Copa del Ayuntamiento de Madrid,
which would later develop into the Copa del Rey (English: "King's Cup"). These
included Barcelona, [Club Español de Fútbol](/wiki/RCD_Espanyol "RCD
Espanyol"), [Club Bizcaya](/wiki/Club_Bizcaya "Club Bizcaya") and [New Foot-
Ball de Madrid](/wiki/Real_Madrid "Real Madrid"). The competition featured the
first recorded game between Barcelona and Madrid FC, with the former emerging
3–1 winners. Club Bizcaya, which consisted of players from both Basque teams,
eventually beat Barcelona in the final. Alfonso XIII subsequently became the
patron of many Spanish football clubs, granting them permission to use "_Real_
" (Spanish for "royal") in their names. Among the many clubs to add the prefix
to their name was Madrid FC, which subsequently became Real Madrid.

Fourteen clubs have won the title: Barcelona (30), Athletic Bilbao (23), Real
Madrid (19), Atlético Madrid (10), Valencia (7), [Real
Zaragoza](/wiki/Real_Zaragoza "Real Zaragoza") (6), Sevilla (5), Espanyol (4),
[Real Union](/wiki/Real_Union "Real Union") (4), Real Betis (2), Deportivo de
La Coruña (2), Real Sociedad (2), [Arenas Club de
Getxo](/wiki/Arenas_Club_de_Getxo "Arenas Club de Getxo") (1) and
[Mallorca](/wiki/RCD_Mallorca "RCD Mallorca") (1).

## Spanish Supercup (Supercopa de
España)[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Football_in_Spain&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: Spanish Supercup \(Supercopa de España\)")]

Main article: [Supercopa de España](/wiki/Supercopa_de_Espa%C3%B1a "Supercopa
de España")

The Spanish Super Cup (Spanish: Supercopa de España) is a championship
organized by Royal Spanish Football Federation and contested by the winners of
La Liga and Copa del Rey. The competition was founded in 1982.

Ten clubs have won the title: Barcelona (12), Real Madrid (10), Deportivo de
La Coruña (3), Atlético Madrid (2), Athletic Bilbao (2), Valencia (1), Real
Zaragoza (1), Mallorca (1), Sevilla (1) and Real Sociedad (1).

## Spanish clubs in international
competitions[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Football_in_Spain&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: Spanish clubs in international competitions")]

Main article: [Spanish football clubs in international
competitions](/wiki/Spanish_football_clubs_in_international_competitions
"Spanish football clubs in international competitions")

The Spanish football clubs are very successful in international competitions.
They are the most successful in different current European competitions, such
as [UEFA Champions League](/wiki/UEFA_Champions_League "UEFA Champions
League"),[23] [UEFA Super Cup](/wiki/UEFA_Super_Cup "UEFA Super Cup"),[24] and
[UEFA Europa League](/wiki/UEFA_Europa_League "UEFA Europa League") ;[25] and
they also were the most successful in the extinct [Inter-Cities Fairs
Cup](/wiki/Inter-Cities_Fairs_Cup "Inter-Cities Fairs Cup").[22]

The most successful clubs in international competitions are Barcelona and Real
Madrid. In addition, other Spanish clubs have also won titles in international
tournaments, such as Atlético Madrid, Valencia, Sevilla, Real Zaragoza,
[Villarreal](/wiki/Villarreal_CF "Villarreal CF"), Deportivo de La Coruña,
[Celta de Vigo](/wiki/Celta_de_Vigo "Celta de Vigo") and
[Málaga](/wiki/M%C3%A1laga_CF "Málaga CF").

Spanish football clubs hold different records in international competitions.

Real Madrid is the most successful club in the European Cup/UEFA Champions
League.[23][53] They have won 13 titles and were runners-up three times. Real
Madrid is also the most successful club in the Intercontinental Cup (three
titles, shared record with A.C. Milan, Peñarol, Boca Juniors, Nacional) and
[FIFA Club World Cup](/wiki/FIFA_Club_World_Cup "FIFA Club World Cup") (three
titles, shared record with Barcelona).

Barcelona is the most successful club in the [FIFA Club World
Cup](/wiki/FIFA_Club_World_Cup "FIFA Club World Cup") (three titles, shared
record with Real Madrid), and it is also the most successful club in the [UEFA
Super Cup](/wiki/UEFA_Super_Cup "UEFA Super Cup") (five titles, shared record
with [Milan](/wiki/A.C._Milan "A.C. Milan")). In addition, Barcelona became
the first football club to win six out of six competitions in a single year
(2009) completing [the sextuple](/wiki/The_Sextuple "The Sextuple"), and the
first European club in history to achieve the [continental
treble](/wiki/Treble_\(association_football\) "Treble \(association
football\)") twice (2009 and 2015).

Sevilla is the most successful club in the UEFA Cup/UEFA Europa League, with
five titles.

In total, the Spanish football clubs have won 73 international titles as of
2018. Over the years, Spanish clubs have won the European Cups/Champions
League 18 times, the UEFA Super Cup 14 times, the [UEFA Cup Winners'
Cup](/wiki/UEFA_Cup_Winners%27_Cup "UEFA Cup Winners' Cup") 7 times, the UEFA
Europa League 11 times, the [UEFA Intertoto Cup](/wiki/UEFA_Intertoto_Cup
"UEFA Intertoto Cup") 7 times and the [Inter-Cities Fairs Cup](/wiki/Inter-
Cities_Fairs_Cup "Inter-Cities Fairs Cup") 6 times. In addition, Spanish clubs
have also won the [Intercontinental
Cup](/wiki/Intercontinental_Cup_\(football\) "Intercontinental Cup
\(football\)") 4 times, and the FIFA Club World Cup 6 times.

## Women's
football[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Football_in_Spain&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: Women's football")]

Main article: [Women's football in Spain](/wiki/Women%27s_football_in_Spain
"Women's football in Spain")

Women's football is a minor sport in Spain.[54][55] Unlike the men's football,
women's football is an amateur sport in Spain. Currently there are two
national competitions, the [League](/wiki/Primera_Divisi%C3%B3n_\(women\)
"Primera División \(women\)") and the [Copa de la
Reina](/wiki/Copa_de_la_Reina_de_F%C3%BAtbol "Copa de la Reina de Fútbol")
(English: Queen's Cup), in the semi-professional clubs involved structure.

The first teams and the first informal women's football competitions in Spain
emerged in the 1970s, although they were not officially recognized by the
Royal Spanish Football Federation until 1980, with the founding of the
National Women's Football Committee. The first official national competition
was the Championships of Spain (Copa de la Reina), established in 1983. The
women's national league began to dispute the 1988-89 season.

The [Spain women's national football
team](/wiki/Spain_women%27s_national_football_team "Spain women's national
football team") has been qualified only once in the [FIFA Women's World
Cup](/wiki/FIFA_Women%27s_World_Cup "FIFA Women's World Cup"), and twice in
the [UEFA Women's Championship](/wiki/UEFA_Women%27s_Championship "UEFA
Women's Championship"). Its youth division have had success in recent times.
The [Spain women's national under-19 football
team](/wiki/Spain_women%27s_national_under-19_football_team "Spain women's
national under-19 football team") won the [UEFA Women's Under-19
Championship](/wiki/UEFA_Women%27s_Under-19_Championship "UEFA Women's
Under-19 Championship") in 2004. The [Spain women's national under-19 football
team](/wiki/Spain_women%27s_national_under-19_football_team "Spain women's
national under-19 football team") won the [UEFA Women's Under-17
Championship](/wiki/UEFA_Women%27s_Under-17_Championship "UEFA Women's
Under-17 Championship") in 2010, 2011, and 2015, as well as their third-place
at the [FIFA U-17 Women's World Cup](/wiki/FIFA_U-17_Women%27s_World_Cup "FIFA
U-17 Women's World Cup").
